Award.AwardTitle: Lattice Gauge Theories, Importance Sampling, and Quantum Unique Ergodicity
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project investigates three classes of questions in probability theories. One class concerns lattice gauge theories, which are discrete approximations of quantum field theories. Quantum field theories are central to the modern understanding of particle physics but do not yet have a firm mathematical foundation, and a proper mathematical understanding of quantum field theories has long been a goal of not only mathematicians, but also of theoretical physicists. This project aims to shed light on some fundamental mathematical questions in this area. A second class of questions involves theoretical properties of importance sampling and various applications of these properties. Importance sampling is central to development of a strong foundation for computational statistics; the results of this work are anticipated to be useful in a wide variety of research areas outside mathematics in which scientific computing is used, including computer science, physics, chemistry, computational biology, and a variety of engineering disciplines. The third class of questions centers on probabilistic techniques for establishing properties of dynamical systems. The questions under study connect several areas of mathematics, including number theory, microlocal analysis, and partial differential equations. The project includes training of graduate students in probability theory and its applications.

The project will study several questions in probability. One class of problems concerns the evaluation of Wilson loop expectations in lattice gauge theories, which has important applications in physics. The project aims to provide a rare rigorous result in this topic, giving the first proper mathematical justification for the famous 1/N expansion of lattice gauge theories. A second class of problems involves theoretical properties of importance sampling and various applications of these properties. The project aims to solve the mathematical problem of determining the minimum sample size required for good performance of importance sampling in any given setting. Lastly, a third class of problems centers around probabilistic techniques for proving that small perturbations of Dirichlet Laplacians are quantum unique ergodic.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main aim of this project was to investigate three classes of problems in probability theory. One class of problems concerned lattice gauge theories, which are discrete approximations of quantum field theories. A second class of problems involved theoretical properties of importance sampling and various applications of these properties. Finally, a third class of problems centered around probabilistic techniques for proving that small perturbations of Dirichlet Laplacians are quantum unique ergodic. 

The main intellectual merits of the project were the following. (1) The evaluation of Wilson loop expectations in lattice gauge theories has important ramifications in the study of quantum field theories. The project provided a rare rigorous result in this topic, giving the first proper mathematical justification the famous 1/N expansion for lattice gauge theories. (2) Importance sampling is a mainstay of modern scientific computing. The project provided a solution of the mathematical problem of determining the minimum sample size required for good performance of importance sampling in any given setting. (3) Quantum unique ergodicity has emerged as an important problem in mathematics in the last ten years. The project demonstrated through a probabilistic argument that arbitrarily small perturbations of Dirichlet Laplacians are quantum unique ergodic, thereby taking a small step towards the bigger goal of showing that generic Laplacian operators are QUE.

The project had a number of broader impacts, the most notable of which were the following. (1) The project on lattice gauge theories had ramifications in the theoretical and mathematical physics communities. It opened up new avenues to a deeper understanding of these physical objects, that are crucial to understanding quantum field theories. (2) The results on important sampling had important consequences in practical applications of importance sampling by statisticians, computer scientists, physicists, chemists, engineers, and others. (3) The topic of quantum unique ergodicity connects diverse topics such as number theory, microlocal analysis and partial differential equations. The project introduced some novel probability theoretic techniques in this field, which enriched the connections between probability and the areas of mathematics that already have a bearing on QUE. 

The project resulted in a large number of peer reviewed publications in major journals and an equally large number of preprints which are currently under review. It also contributed towards the PhD work of four graduate students and the postdoctoral work of one postdoc. The results were disseminated to the community through many conference talks and journal publications.
